title: 344-A
statement: A. Magnetstime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutMad scientist Mike entertains himself by arranging rows of dominoes. He doesn't need dominoes, though: he uses rectangular magnets instead. Each magnet has two poles, positive (a "plus") and negative (a "minus"). If two magnets are put together at a close distance, then the like poles will repel each other and the opposite poles will attract each other.Mike starts by laying one magnet horizontally on the table. During each following step Mike adds one more magnet horizontally to the right end of the row. Depending on how Mike puts the magnet on the table, it is either attracted to the previous one (forming a group of multiple magnets linked together) or repelled by it (then Mike lays this magnet at some distance to the right from the previous one). We assume that a sole magnet not linked to others forms a group of its own.Mike arranged multiple magnets in a row. Determine the number of groups that the magnets formed.InputThe first line of the input contains an integern(1 ≤n≤ 100000) — the number of magnets. Thennlines follow. Thei-th line (1 ≤i≤n) contains either characters "01", if Mike put thei-th magnet in the "plus-minus" position, or characters "10", if Mike put the magnet in the "minus-plus" position.OutputOn the single line of the output print the number of groups of magnets.ExamplesInput6101010011010Output3Input401011010Output2NoteThe first testcase corresponds to the figure. The testcase has three groups consisting of three, one and two magnets.The second testcase has two groups, each consisting of two magnets.

You are given a sequence of $n$ magnets, where each magnet is either "plus-minus" or "minus-plus".  

Determine the number of groups of magnets formed. Two magnets form a group if they are adjacent and have opposite poles. 

**Input:**

* The first line contains an integer $n$ ($1 \le n \le 100000$) representing the number of magnets.
* The following $n$ lines each contain a two-character string representing the polarity of a magnet ("01" for "plus-minus", "10" for "minus-plus").

**Output:**

* A single integer representing the number of groups of magnets.

You are given a sequence of magnets, each with a positive and negative side.  Determine the number of groups of magnets that are connected together. Magnets with opposite sides attract and form a group, while magnets with the same sides repel and stay separate.
